title: HPM 883Spring 2025
text:
HPM 883 is an advanced graduate-level course designed to equip PhD students in the Health Policy and Management program with sophisticated quantitative research skills. This course represents the third installment in the quantitative methods sequence, building on the foundational knowledge acquired in HPM 881 and HPM 882.
Throughout the term, students will delve into advanced quantitative methods pertinent to health services research with a focus on the use of experimental methods and machine learning for causal inference. The course will provide a thorough introduction to machine learning techniques and explore the burgeoning domain of causal machine learning.

title: HPM 883Spring 2025

Throughout the term, students will delve into advanced quantitative methods pertinent to health services research with a focus on the use of experimental methods and machine learning for causal inference. The course will provide a thorough introduction to machine learning techniques and explore the burgeoning domain of causal machine learning.

title: Communication
text:
Slack will be our primary communication hub. An invitation to the course Slack will be shared on the first day of class. Use this place to ask questions, share resources, and engage with your peers, the instructor, and the TA. (For personal matters, please use e-mail)






Important:



Slack will not be continuously monitored by the instructor or TA outside of posted office hours. At other times, students are expected to help/engage with one another to foster a shared learning experience. If a question hasn’t been addressed, the TA or Sean will respond but not immediately or even the same day.
You may DM Sean or the TA in Slack (but, again, don’t expect a response immediately or even the same day.)



The #announcements channel will be used to share course announcements.
Use the #help channel as a first stop for general questions about the class or for technical assistance.
Use the #general channel to discuss lab assignments and discuss/share resources related to course topics.
Use the #interesting-stuff channel to share relevant articles, podcasts, packages, data sources, and anything else relevant that you think your classmates will benefit from.

title: Lab 0
text:
St. Null’s Memorial Hospital is in chaos. Every time the hospital board—led by the well-meaning but trend-obsessed CEO Barnaby Beta—implements a new policy, they find puzzling or contradictory results. Dr. P-Hacker, a self-styled data guru, only adds to the confusion by massaging, cherry-picking, and p-hacking the data until he sees “significance.” Meanwhile, Nurse Random constantly rolls her eyes at his antics and reminds everyone that solid methodology—not creative statistics—should guide decision-making.
But there’s hope. Your class has just been hired as “methodology consultants” to diagnose and treat the hospital’s research woes. In each module (or “episode”), you’ll confront a new fiasco at St. Null’s: from suspiciously overfitted AI models, to missing data nightmares, to bungled randomized trials and flawed observational studies. Along the way, the brilliant but quirky Dr. Doub R. Obust will champion doubly robust methods and other advanced techniques to rescue the day.




Your mission? Use proper causal inference and machine learning strategies to shed light on the true effects of the hospital’s interventions. Each chapter in your lecture notes (i.e., Jupyter notebooks) begins with a brief “scene” in which the hospital staff face some methodological mishap—then shifts to your step-by-step explanation of the relevant statistical concepts and R code. By the end of the course, you’ll have helped St. Null’s Memorial Hospital finally achieve consistent, credible results, while having a bit of comedic fun along the way.

title: Course Introduction
section: Experiments and Machine Learning for HSR
text:
Experiments and Machine Learning for HSR

Causal Inference:

Randomized experiments: the gold standard for testing mechanisms and prioritizing interpretability.

Machine Learning:

Ideal for useful predictions when interpretability or theory is less critical.

Bridging the Divide:

New methods integrate ML principles with causal inference.
Expand theory-building capabilities while testing hypotheses.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Course Summary
Experiments and Machine Learning for Health Services Research
Primary Goal: Equip you with tools to design, analyze, and interpret field experiments and apply machine learning to health services research.

Key Focus Areas:
Field experiments for causal inference.
Machine learning for prediction and causal analysis.
Applications:
Health policy evaluations, resource allocation, and improving healthcare decision-making.

title: Course Introduction
text:
About Me: Dr. Sean Sylvia
Associate Professor, UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health
- Educational Background: PhD in Economics
- Research Focus:
- Experimental methods and causal inference
- Health policy and behavioral economics
- Machine learning for health services research

title: Course Introduction
text:
Proud “Randomista”



Extensive fieldwork using randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and quasi-experiments.

Key projects include:

Field experiments in rural China on health service delivery

Design and evaluation of community health worker interventions

Behavioral incentives and data-driven decision-making in LMICs








Fieldwork Image 1







Fieldwork Image 2

title: Course Introduction
text:
Teaching Assistant: Yumeng Du
PhD Student in Health Policy and Management (Economics Track)
Research Interests:
- Evaluation of digital health programs for underserved populations
Background:
- MSc in Public Health, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM), UK
- MBBS, Central South University, China
- Former RA at UNC-China Project,implementing an RCT on rural telemedicine kiosk program
Role:
- Available for technical support and office hours
- Assisting with labs and project feedback

title: Course Introduction
text:
Increasing Relevance

Health services research increasingly uses:

Experimental methods.
Machine learning tools.

Many causal hypotheses align with predictive relationships between phenomena.
Both approaches add value when combined.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Importance of Reproducibility
Reproducibility in Science

Foundational Principle:

Good experiments are reproducible.
The “reproducibility crisis” has affected some fields.

Reproducibility and ML:

Exploratory analyses, when systematic, help build reliable theories.
ML provides tools for:

Conducting reproducible exploratory research.
Identifying robust treatment effect heterogeneity.

title: Course Introduction
section: Causal Inference as a Missing Data Problem
text:
Causal Inference as a Missing Data Problem

The Fundamental Problem:

We cannot observe a unit in multiple states of the world simultaneously.
Represented as “missing data” in potential outcomes.






Potential Outcomes Table Example




Experimentation Solves under some key assumptions:

SUTVA.
Observability.
Complete Compliance.
Statistical Independence.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Experimental Problems: EP1 & EP2
EP1: Internal Validity

Understanding Effects of Causes:

Do assumptions in the potential outcomes framework hold?
Mediators and moderators.


EP2: External Validity

Generalizability and Scalability:

Would it work in different settings?
Can it scale to create meaningful impact?

title: Course Introduction
text:
Types of Experiments

Lab Experiments:

Controlled settings, abstract framing, imposed rules.

Field Experiments:

Artefactual Field Experiment (AFE): Non-standard subject pool.
Framed Field Experiment (FFE): Adds field-specific context.
Natural Field Experiment (NFE): Subjects unaware they are in an experiment.

Survey Experiments:

Embedded in survey designs.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Criteria Defining Field Experiments

Subjects and Environment:

Selection into experiments.
Nature of tasks, commodities, stakes.

Question: Do experiments require randomization?

Reveal: No, theory can serve as the counterfactual.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Choosing the Right Experiment

Weigh Costs and Benefits:

Benefits:

EP1: Internal validity.
EP2: Generalizability and scalability.

Costs:

Monetary, logistical, and opportunity costs.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Units and Topics

Foundations of Causal Inference:

Missing data problem and potential outcomes.
Randomization and the ATE.

Experimental Design:

Power analysis and randomization strategies.

Machine Learning for Causal Inference:

Lasso, random forests, and causal forests.

Violations of Internal Validity:

SUTVA, compliance issues, and observability.

Scaling and External Validity:

Generalizability and implementation challenges.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Weekly-ish Format

Two sessions per topic:

Lecture: Introduces key concepts and theory.
Lab: Hands-on practice with coding and data analysis.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Flipped(-ish) Classroom Approach

Pre-class readings and recorded materials.
Interactive sessions focused on data exploration and applied learning.
Collaborative problem-solving in small groups.

title: Course Introduction
text:
Assessments

Pre-class Quizzes: Test your understanding of key concepts (10%).
Lab Assignments: Practical applications and analysis (25%).
Exams: Evaluate theoretical and practical understanding (35%).
Pre-analysis Plan: Develop and document a structured analysis plan (15%).
Final Paper: Synthesize course material into a research application (15%).

title: Course Introduction
text:
Resources and Support

Course website with materials and updates: Course Website
Weekly office hours with Dr. Sylvia and Yumeng

title: Course Introduction
section: Randomization recovers the ATE on average.
text: Randomization recovers the ATE on average.
